title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam in the 7th century CE?

options.label: A
options.text: The prophet Muhammad

options.label: B
options.text: Abū Bakr

options.label: C
options.text: Ali

options.label: D
options.text: The Abbasid family

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following was a result of the Umayyad Dynasty's rule?

options.label: A
options.text: They replaced the ruling elite in conquered territories with Muslim officials.

options.label: B
options.text: They allowed local populations to continue their day-to-day customs and religious preferences.

options.label: C
options.text: They extended the empire's reach from present-day Spain to India and made Damascus their capital.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the city built by the Abbasid family as the new capital of the Islamic Empire in 750 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: Mecca

options.label: B
options.text: Medina

options.label: C
options.text: Baghdad

options.label: D
options.text: Damascus

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Mongols' siege of Baghdad in 1258 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: The city was rebuilt and the caliphate was restored.

options.label: B
options.text: The city was destroyed, and the caliph was killed.

options.label: C
options.text: The city was captured, but the caliphate continued to exist.

options.label: D
options.text: The city was abandoned, and the caliphate was overthrown.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Islamic Empire on the world?

options.label: A
options.text: It left a lasting mark on the world through written and spoken Arabic, Islam, and the ideas of its greatest intellectuals.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the decline of other empires and the rise of new powers.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant impact on the world.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a purely military conquest with no lasting effects.

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why art restorers of the past were able to alter paintings with minimal intervention being a threat to their work today?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of heavy varnish to protect paintings.

options.label: B
options.text: The natural aging process of varnishes applied in the past.

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of advanced technology to analyze and remove overpainting.

options.label: D
options.text: The focus on keeping the original work intact with minimal intervention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the technique used to remove the overpainting from the portrait of Isabella of the Italian Medici dynasty?

options.label: A
options.text: X-ray technology

options.label: B
options.text: Varnish removal

options.label: C
options.text: Solvent analysis

options.label: D
options.text: Digital painting

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason behind the alteration of "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid" by Bronzino?

options.label: A
options.text: To make it more visually appealing to modern audiences.

options.label: B
options.text: To obscure risqué details for Victorian England.

options.label: C
options.text: To boost sales by making it more attractive.

options.label: D
options.text: To change the subject of the painting.

multiple-choice.question: How did the team restore the missing sections of Rembrandt's "The Night Watch"?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a team of skilled artists to recreate the lost sections.

options.label: B
options.text: By training an artificial intelligence to digitally paint in Rembrandt's style.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of both A and B.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a different painting as a reference.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of art conservators when restoring altered paintings?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new and improved version of the painting.

options.label: B
options.text: To keep the original work intact with minimal intervention.

options.label: C
options.text: To remove any alterations made in the past.

options.label: D
options.text: To add new details to the painting.

title: A brief history of Spanish - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of modern Spanish comes from Latin?
Which of the following languages had a strong mark on modern Spanish, leaving over a thousand words?

options.label: A
options.text: German

options.label: B
options.text: Arabic

options.label: C
options.text: French

options.label: D
options.text: Italian

multiple-choice.question: In 1492, the Catholic Church consolidated its power through two monarchs, Isabella and Ferdinand, and adopted one of the local languages as the official state language. What was this language?

options.label: A
options.text: Castellano

options.label: B
options.text: Castilian

options.label: C
options.text: Español

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of different languages spoken by the Indigenous population of the Americas?
Why does Spanish retain enough unity of syntax, grammar, and vocabulary to remain one language, despite being spoken in many countries?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has a strong centralized government

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a uniform education system

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has a shared history and cultural heritage

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a unique combination of Latin, Arabic, and Indigenous influences

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: In 1965, the first ever touchscreen was invented to help British air traffic controllers efficiently update flight plans. What was the main reason this technology was not widely adopted?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too expensive.

options.label: B
options.text: It was too unwieldy.

options.label: C
options.text: It was not accurate.

options.label: D
options.text: It was not user-friendly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between capacitive and resistive touchscreens?

options.label: A
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens use a single layer, while resistive touchscreens use two layers.

options.label: B
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens use a conductive material, while resistive touchscreens use an insulator.

options.label: C
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens use an external input to complete their electric circuits, while resistive touchscreens do not.

options.label: D
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens are more durable, while resistive touchscreens are more expensive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why smartphone touchscreens today typically consist of a protective, insulating glass exterior and an LCD screen at the bottom?

options.label: A
options.text: To make them more durable.

options.label: B
options.text: To make them more energy-efficient.

options.label: C
options.text: To make them easier to use.

options.label: D
options.text: To make them more aesthetically pleasing.

multiple-choice.question: Why can your body interact with capacitive touchscreens without the application of force?

options.label: A
options.text: Because your body is a great insulator.

options.label: B
options.text: Because your body is a great conductor.

options.label: C
options.text: Because your body is a great reflector.

options.label: D
options.text: Because your body is a great absorber.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if you try using a smartphone while your hands are wet or gloved?

options.label: A
options.text: The phone's battery will drain faster.

options.label: B
options.text: The phone's screen will become more responsive.

options.label: C
options.text: You'll probably have some trouble interacting with the screen.

options.label: D
options.text: The phone's processor will become more efficient.

title: This weird trick will help you summon an army of worms - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the tradition in which a person uses a metal strip to send deep croaking noises to summon earthworms?

options.label: A
options.text: Worm grunting

options.label: B
options.text: Worm charming

options.label: C
options.text: Fiddling

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to biologist Kenneth Catania, which hypothesis about worm grunting did not hold water?

options.label: A
options.text: Worms were charmed by the noise

options.label: B
options.text: Worms were evading the vibrations

options.label: C
options.text: Worms were fleeing to avoid drowning

options.label: D
options.text: Worms were being pursued by moles

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Charles Darwin's final work, published in 1881, which explored the habits of earthworms?

options.label: A
options.text: "The Formation of Vegetable Mould, Through the Action of Worms, with Observations on their Habits"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Secret Life of Worms"

options.label: C
options.text: "Worms: A Study of Their Behavior"

options.label: D
options.text: "Earthworms: A Natural History"

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the predator that earthworms evolved to escape, and which is abundant in the Florida Panhandle?

options.label: A
options.text: Eastern moles

options.label: B
options.text: Herring gulls

options.label: C
options.text: Wood turtles

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: Why does the behavior of worms surfacing in response to worm grunting persist, even though it makes them more vulnerable to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans are a more frequent predator than moles

options.label: B
options.text: Because worms have not yet evolved to escape humans

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is beneficial for a prey species to maintain its adaptations against a more frequent predator

options.label: D
options.text: Because worm grunting is a natural behavior that cannot be changed

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

multiple-choice.question: In 2020, Mali produced an estimated 71.2 tons of gold. However, the country only saw $850 million from gold that year. What is the main reason for this discrepancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Overestimation of gold production

options.label: B
options.text: Underestimation of gold value

options.label: C
options.text: Greed on an individual, corporate, and national scale, and a corrupt system that perpetuates itself

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of infrastructure to mine and export gold

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that multinational corporations exploit Mali's need for tax revenue?

options.label: A
options.text: By paying higher taxes than required

options.label: B
options.text: By signing favorable contracts that benefit both parties

options.label: C
options.text: By taking advantage of loopholes in the tax system, such as exporting large amounts of gold without paying taxes

options.label: D
options.text: By investing in Mali's infrastructure and economy

multiple-choice.question: How do multinational corporations evade taxes they are legally required to pay?

options.label: A
options.text: By paying taxes on time and in full

options.label: B
options.text: By filtering profits through a labyrinth of tax havens that's difficult to trace

options.label: C
options.text: By exaggerating their expenses so they end up owing very little in taxes

options.label: D
options.text: By donating a portion of their profits to Mali's government

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of gold smuggling on a massive scale in Africa?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in tax revenue for gold-rich countries

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in poverty rates among citizens of gold-rich countries

options.label: C
options.text: A vicious cycle of reliance on corporations that perpetuate the situation

options.label: D
options.text: An improvement in the economy and infrastructure of gold-rich countries

multiple-choice.question: What is the main consequence of the corrupt system and greed on an individual, corporate, and national scale in Mali?

options.label: A
options.text: More than half of Mali's citizens live below the international poverty line, while their nation's wealth lines the pockets of foreign corporations and corrupt officials

options.label: A
options.text: A significant increase in tax revenue for Mali's government

options.label: B
options.text: An improvement in the country's infrastructure and economy

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in the number of poor citizens in Mali

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated risk of extinction or the unrecoverable collapse of human civilization from natural causes?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 in 10,000 per century

options.label: B
options.text: 1 in 100 per century

options.label: C
options.text: 1 in 1,000 per century

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 100,000 per century

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern with engineered pandemics?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of pandemics through biowarfare and research accidents

options.label: B
options.text: The decrease in the cost of genome sequencing and modification

options.label: C
options.text: The increase in the number of people and groups who could potentially create deadly pathogens

options.label: D
options.text: The potential for pandemics to be caused by naturally occurring germs

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 10 times higher

options.label: B
options.text: More than 10 times higher

options.label: C
options.text: More than 100 times higher

options.label: D
options.text: More than 1,000 times higher

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary concern with unaligned AI?

options.label: A
options.text: The potential for AI to surpass human abilities and pose an existential risk

options.label: B
options.text: The potential for AI to be used for biowarfare

options.label: C
options.text: The potential for AI to cause pandemics

options.label: D
options.text: The potential for AI to be used for climate change

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point made about the risk of human extinction or the unrecoverable collapse of human civilization?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an inherent risk that cannot be controlled

options.label: B
options.text: It is a risk that is solely caused by natural causes

options.label: C
options.text: It is a risk that is within human control and can be reduced

options.label: D
options.text: It is a risk that is solely caused by climate change

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of Lactobacilli bacteria in the vagina?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce an acid that raises the vagina's pH.

options.label: B
options.text: To combat and outcompete Candida yeasts for nutrients and territory.

options.label: C
options.text: To secrete enzymes that degrade epithelial cells.

options.label: D
options.text: To disrupt the balance of the vaginal microbiome.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the species of Candida yeasts that is the usual culprit of vaginal thrush or yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Candida albicans

options.label: B
options.text: Candida glabrata

options.label: C
options.text: Candida tropicalis

options.label: D
options.text: Candida parapsilosis

multiple-choice.question: What is a major factor that can make people more susceptible to vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: A strong immune system

options.label: B
options.text: Antibiotic treatments

options.label: C
options.text: A balanced diet

options.label: D
options.text: Regular exercise

multiple-choice.question: What is a recommended way to wash the vulva to prevent yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Using soap and water

options.label: B
options.text: Using hot water and a loofah

options.label: C
options.text: Gently washing with water

options.label: D
options.text: Using a vaginal wash

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential solution to treating some yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Using antifungal medications

options.label: B
options.text: Using probiotics containing harmless yeasts

options.label: C
options.text: Using antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Using hormone replacement therapy

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of a 2017 car accident involving a truck carrying thousands of kilograms of live hagfish?

options.label: A
options.text: The highway was littered with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime that took the fire department 7 hours to clear.

options.label: B
options.text: The hagfish escaped and swam away unharmed.

options.label: C
options.text: The truck was damaged, but no one was injured.

options.label: D
options.text: The hagfish were delivered to their destination safely.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the slime produced by hagfish?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract predators

options.label: B
options.text: To defend against predators

options.label: C
options.text: To communicate with other hagfish

options.label: D
options.text: To attract prey

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the structure of a hagfish's body that allows it to slip out of the way when attacked by a predator?

options.label: A
options.text: Its skin is tightly attached to its muscles

options.label: B
options.text: Its skin is loosely attached to its muscles

options.label: C
options.text: Its bones are flexible and can bend

options.label: D
options.text: Its organs are encased in a protective shell

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of hagfish slime in the field of athletic and safety gear?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be used to create lightweight and breathable fabrics

options.label: B
options.text: It can be used to create non-renewable petroleum-based fibers

options.label: C
options.text: It can be used to create sustainable and strong fibers that rival nylon

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used to create waterproof and windproof clothing

multiple-choice.question: How long can hagfish survive without oxygen?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: 12 hours

options.label: C
options.text: 36 hours

options.label: D
options.text: 72 hours

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the number that most governments rely on to answer the question of which country is the best to live in?

options.label: A
options.text: Gross National Happiness

options.label: B
options.text: Human Development Index

options.label: C
options.text: Sustainable Development Index

options.label: D
options.text: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a major limitation of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as a measure of well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not account for the value of public services

options.label: B
options.text: It only measures the income of the wealthy

options.label: C
options.text: It does not take into account the environmental impact of economic growth

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Human Development Index

options.label: B
options.text: Sustainable Development Index

options.label: C
options.text: Gross National Happiness

options.label: D
options.text: Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Colombia

options.label: C
options.text: Jordan

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Using a single number, such as GDP

options.label: B
options.text: Using a dashboard approach that lays out multiple factors

options.label: C
options.text: Using a combination of GDP and other metrics

options.label: D
options.text: Using no metrics at all

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate percentage of barometric pressure at the top of Mt. Everest compared to sea level?
What is the name of the condition that occurs when the body is unable to adapt to high altitudes and oxygen levels are depleted?

options.label: A
options.text: AMS (Acute Mountain Sickness)

options.label: B
options.text: HACE (High-Altitude Cerebral Edema)

options.label: C
options.text: HAPE (High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema)

options.label: D
options.text: Altitude Sickness

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary adaptation that occurs in the body when it is exposed to high altitudes for an extended period?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased hemoglobin levels

options.label: C
options.text: Increased blood plasma volume

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased oxygen absorption

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process by which the body adapts to high altitudes by increasing the concentration of hemoglobin in the blood?

options.label: A
options.text: Ventilatory Acclimatization

options.label: B
options.text: Hemoglobin Adaptation

options.label: C
options.text: Acclimatization

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygenation

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition that occurs when fluid builds up in the brain due to high altitudes and low oxygen levels?

options.label: A
options.text: HACE (High-Altitude Cerebral Edema)

options.label: B
options.text: HAPE (High-Altitude Pulmonary Edema)

options.label: C
options.text: Altitude Sickness

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen Deprivation

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with many of the cultural artifacts in the British Museum?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too old and fragile to be displayed.

options.label: B
options.text: They are disputed and claimed by their original owners.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not well-documented and lack historical context.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not suitable for modern audiences.

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1897 led to the British taking thousands of cultural artifacts from the Kingdom of Benin?

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin War

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin Disaster

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin Expedition

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin Invasion

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the group formed in 2007 to discuss the potential return of the Benin bronzes to Nigeria?

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin Dialogue Group

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin Repatriation Committee

options.label: C
options.text: The British Museum Task Force

options.label: D
options.text: The Nigerian Cultural Heritage Committee

multiple-choice.question: Why is the British Museum restricted from returning cultural artifacts to their original owners?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of a government act that prevents it from doing so.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has no funds to facilitate the return of artifacts.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has no interest in returning the artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it believes the artifacts are better off in the museum.

multiple-choice.question: What is the broader issue that the return of cultural artifacts is a part of?

options.label: A
options.text: A dispute over museum ownership.

options.label: B
options.text: A legacy of colonial power and cultural identity.

options.label: C
options.text: A question of cultural preservation.

options.label: D
options.text: A debate over museum funding.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way parrots produce human speech?

options.label: A
options.text: They use a different organ in their throat to produce sound.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a highly developed sense of hearing.

options.label: C
options.text: They use their syrinx, located at the base of their windpipe, to produce sound.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to shape their vocalizations using their tongue and lips.

multiple-choice.question: Why are parrots able to imitate a wide range of sounds, including the human voice?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a highly developed sense of hearing.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a need for sophisticated mimicry due to their social behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a highly developed sense of smell.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a highly developed sense of vision.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the anatomy of a parrot's tongue and beak?

options.label: A
options.text: Their tongues are rigid and their beaks are flexible.

options.label: B
options.text: Their tongues are flexible and their beaks are rigid.

options.label: C
options.text: Their tongues are short and their beaks are long.

options.label: D
options.text: Their tongues are long and their beaks are short.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the parrot that became the first non-human animal to pose an existential question?

options.label: A
options.text: Alex

options.label: B
options.text: Polly

options.label: C
options.text: Charlie

options.label: D
options.text: Max

multiple-choice.question: Why are wild parrot populations decreasing?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are being overhunted by humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are losing their habitats to deforestation.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are being poached by pet traders.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.
